authors: Tang Pei;Shao Shiyong;Zhan Jie;Wang Yingjian;Zhou Liangping;Hu Zhiyuan;Mu Yuan
title: Mixed sources of water-soluble inorganic ions over the northeastern Tibetan Plateau: Anthropogenic aerosol transport versus salt lake emissions
abstract:
•Secondary inorganic aerosols originate from the long-range transport of anthropogenic emissions. •Salt lakes on the Tibetan Plateau produce large amounts of chloride ions. •Due to livestock emissions in local pastoral areas, ammonium dominates water-soluble inorganic ions. •The low PM2.5/PM10values demonstrate the predominance of coarse particles in the regional aerosol. 
 To understand the physicochemical properties, size distribution, and pollution sources of aerosols in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau (TP), an intensive field observation campaign was conducted in the Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture during the summer of 2023. Field observations integrated optical particle counting and ion chromatography, supported by principal component analysis (PCA) and trajectory clustering. Water-soluble inorganic ions (WSII) were dominated by NH4+, followed by NO3−, SO42−, and Cl−. Secondary inorganic aerosols (SIA) showed a strong positive correlation with each other, but a weaker correlation with Cl−. SIA and Cl− ions originated from different emission sources. The mass concentration size distribution exhibited a bimodal pattern dominated by an accumulation mode peak at 0.25 μm and a coarse mode peak at 5 μm with the coarse mode accounting for 89 % of the total mass concentration. Coarse particles constituted the dominant fraction of aerosols, as evidenced by the PM2.5/PM10 ratio of 0.2. SIA was positively correlated with accumulation mode particles (R2 = 0.21), whereas there was no linear relationship with coarse mode aerosols (R2 = 0.01). PCA revealed that regional anthropogenic pollution is the dominant source. Three industrial cities in low-altitude regions were identified as potential source areas of SIA and accumulation mode aerosol, while chloride ions were derived from salt lakes on the plateau. The present study quantified the chemical composition of atmospheric aerosols in the northeastern TP and resolved their mixing sources.

explanation: 该研究论文探讨了热带沿海大气中气溶胶的吸湿特性及其对光散射的影响，重点关注相对湿度对气溶胶含水量、光学性质和化学成分的调节作用。研究通过测量不同相对湿度条件下的气溶胶散射系数，分析了气溶胶的增长因子和化学成分，揭示了无机气溶胶在调节气溶胶散射特性中的重要作用。此外，研究还发现有机气溶胶的含水量在较高相对湿度下显著增加，可能促进了无机气溶胶（特别是硫酸盐）的生成。这些结果对于理解大气气溶胶的形成机制和吸湿特性，以及评估其对气候的影响具有重要意义，与大气环境遥感技术中的空气质量监测和大气成分分析密切相关。
topic_words: ['aerosol scattering', 'hygroscopicity', 'aerosol water content', 'atmospheric composition', 'air quality']
authors: Sobhan Kumar Kompalli;S. Suresh Babu
title: Aerosol light-scattering enhancement and liquid water content in a tropical coastal atmosphere
abstract:
•Aerosol growth due to increased RH levels resulted in a > 35 % increase in aerosol total scattering coefficients. •A higher aerosol scattering growth factor during the day than at night due to increased hygroscopicity. •Secondary aerosols, especially oxygenated organics and sulfate, contributed to enhanced hygroscopicity. •Exponential increase in aerosol water uptake at elevated RH levels with mass growth factors as high as 10–12. •Increasing amounts of inorganics were found with increasing ALWCorganicsat ambient RH >85 %. 
 Ambient relative humidity (RH) determines the aerosol water content and modulates aerosol optical properties, chemical composition, and mixing state. Understanding aerosol hygroscopicity is crucial for assessing its climate forcing. In this study, aerosol hygroscopic properties were characterized using the measurements of aerosol scattering coefficients (σsp) at varying RH conditions over a tropical coastal environment in the Indian region. The observations were carried out using an aerosol conditioning system consisting of dry (RH <40 %) and wet nephelometers (60–85 %) from 24 December 2019 to 4 January 2020 (winter) and from 3 November 2020 to 30 November 2020 (post-monsoon). The aerosol light-scattering enhancement factor, f(RH) (the ratio of σsp measured by wet and dry nephelometers), was calculated and parameterized using an aerosol growth function. The overall mean dry aerosol total scattering coefficient at 550 nm was 170 ± 72 Mm−1 and 155 ± 61 Mm−1, whereas aerosol light-scattering enhancement factors at 85 % RH, i.e., f(RH = 85 %, 550 nm), were in the range of 1.45–1.48. A higher scattering enhancement (5–8 %) was observed during the sea-breeze periods than the land-breeze periods. Composite aerosol hygroscopicity (κchem) values derived from the concurrent non-refractory submicron aerosol (NR-PM1) chemical composition also reflected contrasting aerosol systems within a day. Aerosol growth function parameter (γ) depicted a well-defined association with the mass fraction of inorganic aerosols, suggesting their prominent role in regulating aerosol scattering properties. Detailed analysis performed to elucidate the role of elevated RH levels (RH > 85 %) revealed that the aerosol liquid water content (ALWC) showed a step enhancement with corresponding mass growth factors (the ratio of mass loading in dry and wet conditions) increasing to as high as 10 to 12. At elevated RH conditions, the ALWC associated with organic aerosol (OA) (ALWCorganics), which is the dominant species in the NR-PM1 aerosol system, also increased significantly. Such enhanced ALWC and hygroscopicity (κorganics) of organics possibly contributed to the increased aqueous-phase production of inorganic aerosols (especially sulfate), as inferred from a significant correlation (r > 0.8) between the parameters. These results highlighted the role played by ambient RH in controlling aerosol formation pathways and their hygroscopic properties over the highly humid tropical atmosphere.

explanation: 该论文主要评估了极地优化的WRF模型中不同的云微物理方案在模拟斯瓦尔巴特地区低层大气过程中的表现。研究重点在于不同方案对地表辐射和大气垂直结构的模拟效果，特别是在冬季和夏季。论文发现，云微物理方案的选择对地表辐射的模拟有显著影响，并且大多数方案在冬季高估了低层混合相云中的冰含量。虽然云是大气环境的重要组成部分，但该研究并没有直接涉及大气环境遥感技术，如空气质量监测、卫星观测或大气成分分析，而是侧重于云微物理过程的模拟和评估。
topic_words: ['Cloud microphysics', 'Surface radiation', 'Atmospheric vertical structure', 'Mixed-phase clouds', 'Polar-WRF model', 'Svalbard', 'Arctic']
authors: Zilu Zhang;Shupo Ma;Wei Cheng;Jinhuan Zhu;Peng Li;Fei Li;Libo Zhou
title: Evaluation of Polar-WRF microphysics schemes for simulations of lower atmospheric processes in the Svalbard region, Arctic
abstract:
•Season-dependent scheme performance identified for Arctic simulations. •Most schemes overestimate ice content in winter low-level mixed-phase clouds. •Cloud simulation errors drive surface longwave radiation biases. •Reveal large microphysics scheme discrepancies in the Svalbard, Arctic. 
 Clouds play a critical role in climate change and the energy budget in the Arctic. The parameterization of cloud microphysics is crucial for simulating surface radiation and atmospheric vertical structure in the Arctic region. This study evaluates the performance of eight widely used cloud microphysics schemes in the Svalbard region during winter and summer, utilizing field observation data and the polar-optimized Weather Research and Forecasting model (Polar-WRF). The results demonstrated that the choice of cloud microphysics scheme significantly influences surface radiation and simulations of the lower atmosphere. During winter, the Thompson, Morrison, and NSSL schemes effectively simulate surface radiation, whereas the Lin, Goddard, and WSM6 schemes excel in capturing the vertical structure of the atmosphere. In summer, the WSM6 and Thompson schemes show superior performance in simulating surface radiation, whereas the Thompson, Morrison, and CAM5.1 schemes better represent atmospheric profiles. The accuracy of cloud simulations is crucial for surface radiation, as all schemes tend to underestimate downward longwave radiation, primarily due to an overestimation of low cloud cover. In addition, challenges in simulating mixed-phase clouds, which are prevalent in the Svalbard region, were identified, with most schemes overestimating the ice water content and underestimating the liquid water content in winter. In summer, models tend to underestimate the cloud height and liquid water content of low-level clouds. These findings highlight the importance of accurately simulating low-level mixed-phase clouds to improve the understanding of surface–atmosphere interactions in the Arctic.

title: Main and interaction effects of drivers on compound dry-hot events in the middle-lower Yangtze River Basin using explainable machine learning
abstract:
•Integrated meteorological, soil moisture, and circulation indices with SHAP and interaction-SHAP analysis. •Identified vapor pressure deficit (VPD) as the dominant driver of compound drought–heat events (CDHEs). •Found that circulation factors and precipitation gain importance at longer temporal scales. •Revealed that cross-scale couplings, especially VPD–Z500, intensify CDHE severity and persistence. 
 Compound dry-hot events (CDHEs), characterized by the concurrence of drought and heat extremes, have become increasingly frequent and severe under climate change, posing significant risks to ecosystems, agriculture, and human society. Understanding the dominant drivers and their interactions across different temporal scales is critical for advancing prediction and attribution of such events. In this study, we develop regression models of the Standardized Compound Drought and Heat Index (SCDHI) at weekly, bi-weekly, and four-week scales for the middle-lower Yangtze River Basin. The models incorporate land-surface and near-surface factors—temperature, soil moisture, vapor pressure deficit (VPD), and precipitation-together with large-scale atmospheric circulation indices, including the 500-hPa geopotential height (Z500) and the strength (WS) and area (WA) of the western Pacific subtropical high. By applying explainable machine learning approaches-Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP), we systematically quantify the direct contributions of individual variables and their pairwise interactions. Results show that VPD is the most influential driver of CDHEs across all time scales. Circulation factors (Z500, WA, WS) and precipitation become increasingly important at longer scales, underscoring the influence of mid-tropospheric circulation patterns and the western Pacific subtropical high in sustaining extreme events. Notably, interactions across scales-from large-scale circulation anomalies (e.g., Z500) to near-surface atmospheric demand (e.g., VPD) - intensify with both event severity and time scale, underscoring the compound nature of CDHE formation. Overall, this study provides a comprehensive multi-scale attribution framework for CDHEs, demonstrating the added value of combining deep learning regression models with explainable artificial intelligence techniques. The findings not only enhance understanding of the physical mechanisms driving CDHEs but also offer methodological insights for future climate attribution and risk management in drought- and heat-prone regions.
